text: [Music]
northeastern Nigeria is littered with
thousands of land mines and improvised
explosives after almost a decade of
conflict in the region the Islamist
group Boko Haram continues to attack
times and villages and to kidnap
hundreds of schoolgirls most notoriously
from the town of chibok in 2014 the
number of people being killed and
injured by mines and explosives in
Nigeria has greatly increased according
to research by the mine advisory group
over 160 killed in the past two years
with hundreds more injured it's had a
devastating impact on the region and
prevents large areas of land from being
farmed and it's a familiar pattern
across the globe so how many land mines
are there around the world minefields
often the deadly remnants of war left
behind long after the combatants have
gone under international law when mines
are laid they must be mapped so they can
be removed safely at the later days all
too often they're not mapped or maps are
lost and the process of de mining can be
a slow and dangerous one
in 2016 post-conflict clearance
operations undertaken by charities such
as the halo trust destroyed over 200,000
anti-personnel and 20,000 anti-vehicle
mines around the world but this hardly
scratches the surface of the problem
there are still an estimated 110 million
anti-personnel mines still on the ground
with more being laid every year in
active conflict areas in a single year
as many as 8,000 people are killed or
seriously injured many of them children
that's almost one person killed or
injured every hour of every day that
figure has risen as a result of the
widespread use of improvised explosive
devices by non-government forces who are
far less likely to keep a record of
where these mines have been placed 2016
had the highest number of recorded cases
of homemade devices being used Boko
Haram used pipes and pots to make their
explosives so where in the world are
mines and unexploded munitions they're
right across the globe in over 60
countries it's unknown how contaminated
Nigeria is but mine action review
reports that Boko Haram strongholds are
heavily mined it's not a problem that's
going to end anytime soon
at the present rate of clearance it
would still take 500 years to remove all
the Buried explosive devices around the
wild
